--- In junit@y..., Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@b...> wrote:
> You have several options:
> - create your own TestCase that doesn't extend the standard TestCase

We've done that, but I would rather not rewrite the JUnit core. I 
would prefer for the core to be flexible enough to handle multiple 
failures and I will provide the TestRunner that formats the results.

> DbC's asserts are to be placed in the production code, and not 
(only) in 
> the test code.  Like I said in a previous mail, you should prefer 
the 
> JDK1.4 assert keyword because it can be turned off when generating 
the 
> production release (if you don't use JDK1.4, well...).

I think that DbC can also be done with AspectJ or we can remove 
asserts from our code with a Java parser.

Regards,

David
